stem: A client with sickle cell disease (SCD) received 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) for severe anemia 5 days ago. The client now returns with a hemoglobin level LOWER than before the transfusion. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Paradoxical anemia post-transfusion.
Background: HbSS. Pre-transfusion Hgb was 6.2 g/dL. 2 units PRBCs given.
Assessment: Current Hgb is 4.8 g/dL. Urine is very dark (Hemoglobinuria).
Recommendation: Stabilization without additional blood.

tabs.title: Hematology & Transfusion Log
tabs.content:
Test ItemBaseline (Pre-Transfusion)Today (Post-Transfusion)
Hemoglobin (Hgb)6.2 g/dL4.8 g/dL (Critical Drop)
Reticulocyte Count12%1% (Suppressed)
Urine ColorAmberDark/Black (Cola)
Indirect Bilirubin2.2 mg/dL8.4 mg/dL (Massive Hemolysis)

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 90/58 mmHg, HR 132 bpm, RR 26 breaths/min, T 102.4°F (39.1°C). Client is profoundly weak.

actionOptions.text: Avoid further blood transfusions, as they will worsen the hemolysis.
Prepare to administer IVIG or high-dose corticosteroids.
Increase the IV rate of blood to 150 mL/hr to rescue the Hgb.
Encourage the client to drink iron-fortified juices.

parameterOptions.text: Hemoglobin (Hgb) levels and reticulocyte count trends.
Urine color and presence of hemoglobinuria (cola-colored urine).
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose.
Presence of a positive Trousseau sign.

rationale.correct: This is Hyperhemolysis Syndrome (HHS) (c2). It is a life-threatening, paradoxical complication of transfusion in SCD patients where the body destroys *both* the transfused donor cells and the patient's own native cells. The key cue is the Hgb dropping BELOW the pre-transfusion baseline (from 6.2 g/dL down to 4.8 g/dL). Priority action #1 is AVOIDING further blood (a1), as more blood will ignite more hemolysis. Priority #2 is immunosuppression with IVIG/corticosteroids (a2). Key parameters include tracking the critical Hgb levels and reticulocyte count trends (p1) and monitoring for hemoglobinuria (p2).
clinicalPearls: In HHS, the Hgb drops, the Retic count drops (paradoxically), and the Bilirubin spikes.
This is one of the few anemic emergencies where the answer is 'DO NOT GIVE BLOOD.'
Always notify the blood bank if a patient develops severe anemia immediately following a transfusion.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the Hgb is 4.8 g/dL, so the answer must be 'Give more blood quickly.'
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In SCD, if the Hgb is lower than the starting point, more blood is detrimental. It's like adding fuel to a fire. Use IVIG instead.

mnemonic.title: Hyper-Hemi
mnemonic.expansion: H-Hgb drops lower. H-Heat (Fever). H-Halt blood transfusions! H-High-dose steroids.
